prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We will use one baseband to observe HCO+ (3-2) and HCN (3-2) - as described in the proposal text, the HCO+ line is chosen as an ideal tracer of disk kinematics based on both published studies that use this tracer and our unpublished SMA data (see Figure 2 in the proposal). The HCN line is included as a secondary tracer of disk kinematics.
In order to reliably trace Keplerian rotation, we require detections to at least 2 km/s from rest (see sensitivity section for more details). We thus enter a linewidth of 2 km/s. Since the inclinations of these disks are not known a priori, we require very high spectral resolution to ensure that the rotation curve can be accurately resolved even for nearly face-on systems. We thus select the narrowest bandwidth for each line (66 km/s) and the highest spectral resolution (0.08 km/s). We will then smooth to 0.1 km/s. For disks viewed at more moderate or face-on inclinations we will smooth to lower spectral resolution if higher S/N is required.
The other three basebands will be used to measure the continuum. Our program generates a very modest data rate of only 3.66 MB/s.

Our program depends on spatially resolving disks with ~50 AU resolution, where this specific resolution is chosen to match that of an SMA survey of T Tauri stars to which we will compare (Andrews et al. 2009, 2010). Our requested angular resolution of 0.13" corresponds to linear resolutions of 52-57 AU at the distances to our targets (400-440) pc, meeting this goal to within ~10%.
The largest angular scale of 1.5" (600-660 AU at the target distances of 400-440 pc) is chosen so that the disks, with radii 100-300 AU, are guaranteed to be fully recovered.
With these choices only one configuration is required (the C36-6 configuration), and the ACA is not required.

Our sensitivity is driven by the requirement of detecting HCO+ (3-2) emission in 0.1 km/s channels up to at least 2 km/s from rest, in order to derive accurate rotation curves for these disks. Based on the SMA data shown in Figure 2 in the proposal, V883 Ori has an intensity of 350 mJy at 2 km/s from rest. The emission in each channel is very compact and unresolved, thus we expect a similar intensity in the much higher resolution ALMA observations. We scale this down by a factor of ten, since the least massive disks in our sample are ~10x less massive than V883 Ori (see Table 1 in the proposal), giving an expected intensity of 35 mJy at 2 km/s. As the rotation curve will be derived by centroiding the emission in each velocity channel, and accurate centroiding requires at least a 5sigma detection, our required rms is thus 7 mJy in 0.1 km/s channels.
Based on the continuum fluxes measured with the SMA, we will detect the continuum with extremely high significance (likely to at least 1000sigma). While the nominal dynamic range is 100, we anticipate improving upon this through appropriate use of self-calibration. However, even if we are unable to exceed the nominal dynamic range of 100, we will still be able to detect the signatures of disk fragmentation (fragments and spiral structure), should they exist, given that these features are all brighter than 1% of the peak flux in the simulations published by Vorobyov et al. (2013).

We will use one baseband to observe HCO+ (3-2) and HCN (3-2) - as described in the proposal text, the HCO+ line is chosen as an ideal tracer of disk kinematics based on both published studies that use this tracer and our unpublished SMA data (see Figure 2 in the proposal). prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: FU Orionis objects (FUors) are young stars observed to flare by several magnitudes in the optical and remain bright for decades or longer, with the flares attributed to enhanced accretion from surrounding disks. FUors may represent the optically visible, late stages of a cycle of episodic accretion throughout the protostellar stage of star formation, or they may represent an extreme, unique class of young stars; debate continues on this topic. A range of possible driving mechanisms for the accretion bursts have been proposed, including disk gravitational instabilities, thermal instabilities, a combination of gravitational and magneto-rotational instabilities, and binary interactions. The physical structure of FUor disks and the host star masses, both key ingredients for a complete understanding of the physical origin of these extreme accretion events, remain unknown. We propose a survey of FUors at 0.1" resolution. With these data we will spatially resolve the disks, accurately map their gas kinematics, and characterize both the spatial distribution and total amount of mass in FUor systems, providing key observational constraints on burst driving mechanisms.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory, Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics
